title: At least 4 deaths in Houston , official says , as storms bring  life - threatening  flood risk to Texas and Louisiana
message:
At least 4 deaths in Houston as storms bring 'life-threatening' flood risk to Texas and LouisianaAt least four people are dead in Houston after hurricane-force winds and torrential rains tore a damaging path through the city Thursday.
Power outages left more than 1 million homes and businesses in the dark across the state on Thursday, with the torrential storms pounding an already-soaked South.
A few spots caught under multiple torrential storms may pick up 8 inches or more of rain.
Texas and Louisiana have been in the bull's-eye of seemingly unrelenting rounds of torrential, flooding downpours since the start of April.
A tornado warning had been issued earlier Thursday evening in Harris County, Texas, including downtown Houston, according to the National Weather Service.

title: High risk of extreme rainfall to trigger  life - threatening  flooding in Texas , Louisiana
message:
A dangerous, life-threatening flash flooding event is unfolding Thursday as torrential storms pound the already-soaked U.S. South.
A rare Level 4 of 4 high risk of excessive rainfall was issued for parts of eastern Texas and western Louisiana by the Weather Prediction Center Thursday.
Rainfall rates up to three inches per hour are possible in the heaviest storms, which could lead to life-threatening flash flooding, according to the WPC.
Serious flash flooding is likely in any areas caught under multiple storms unloading two to three inches of rain per hour.
An initial round of flash flooding is likely in the first half of Friday before rain starts to taper off in the afternoon.

- A dangerous flash flooding event is currently unfolding in parts of the U.S. South
- Torrential storms are pummeling the already-soaked U.S. South
-  A Level 4 of 4 high risk of excessive rainfall was issued in Texas and Louisiana
- Rainfall rates of up to three inches per hour are possible
- A life-threatening flash flooding situation is underway
- an initial round of flash flooding is likely on Friday

title: April enigma - Newspaper - DAWN . COM
message:
Moving eastward, in April, southern China experienced over double the normal precipitation for the month, the second-highest level since 1961.
In early April, the Indus River System Authority (Irsa) predicted a 30 per cent water shortage in the early Kharif season.
(This was subsequently reversed after improved Kabul river flows.)
A flood of over 110,000 cusecs in the Kabul river augmented flows in the Indus zone.
By the end of April, the country received rainfall which was more than 150pc of the usual for the month.
event_breakdown:
The natural-disaster events in the text are as follows:

1. Heavy precipitation in southern China in April (April 2022)
2. Water shortage in the early Kharif season in the Indus River System (April 2022)
3. Flood of over 110,000 cusecs in the Kabul river (April 2022)
4. Above-normal rainfall in Pakistan in April (April 2022)

title: Apprehension As Failed Edo N30bn Water Storm Project Escalates Flooding
message:
On a yearly basis, residents of such areas lose their property to the flooding, which in some cases leads to the loss of lives.
Despite the N30 billion water storm project embarked upon by the then administration of Comrade Adams Oshiomhole, the issue of flooding in some parts of the state capital has persisted.
Governor Godwin Obaseki in addressing flooding in the state had promised to complete the Benin water storm project initiated by his predecessor (Oshiomhole).
Igho lamented, “The main cause of this flooding in the area was as a result of the blockage of the moat and diversion of water from other areas.
He added that the state government would provide support to those displaced from their homes by the rising water level occasioned by flooding.
event_breakdown:
1- Flooding in some parts of the state capital of Benin
2- Blockage of the moat and diversion of water from other areas

title: Four deaths confirmed from severe storm that ravaged Houston
message:
(Reuters) - A severe storm packing hurricane-force winds pummeled Houston on Thursday, killing at least four people, blowing windows out of high-rise buildings and leaving some 800,000 homes without power as much of the city was plunged into darkness, the mayor said.
The mayor said at least four storm-related fatalities had been confirmed, mostly from fallen trees.
Whitmire delivered similar initial storm assessments during a brief televised news conference carried live a short time after his interview.
The mayor said the severe weather had caught many residents by surprise, recounting that he was attending a little league baseball game when the storm hit, "and we had very little time to get to cover."
The National Weather Service also issued a flood watch for the Houston area from heavy rains associated with the storm.
event_breakdown:
Natural-disaster events in the text:
-Four people were confirmed dead in Houston.
-High winds caused by a severe storm knocked windows out of Houston buildings.
-Approximately 800,000 homes were without electricity in the Houston area after winds knocked power lines down.
-The National Weather Service issued a flood watch for the Houston area.

title: Kona low brings bursts of rain and occasional sunny skies to disaster - weary Maui
message:
HONOLULU (HawaiiNewsNow) - A disaster-weary Maui braced Thursday for the potential of severe weather.
What they got was a mixed bag: Bursts of rain, strong winds and then sunny skies.
Amos Lonokailua-Hewett, administrator for Maui’s Emergency Management Agency, said county crews have been preparing for severe weather since last week.
But HNN spotted at least one canal near the intersection of South Kihei and North Kihei roads that had not been cleared.
In South Maui, meanwhile, the ocean was brown and choppy.
event_breakdown:
- A disaster-weary Maui is preparing for severe weather.
- County crews have been preparing for severe weather since last week.
- A canal near the intersection of South Kihei and North Kihei roads had not been cleared.
- The ocean in South Maui was brown and choppy.

message:
Here's a closer look at what holdover fires are and their threat to Western Canada.
The BC Wildfire Service defines a holdover as "a fire that remains dormant and undetected for a considerable time after it starts."
When the conditions are right, fires burning deep underground can "slumber" undetected, simmering even under snow for possibly months after ignition.

title: Govt moves to build temporary drainage on Kasoa road
message:
The Government is set to construct a temporary drainage as a matter of urgency on the Kasoa to Winneba section of the N1 to mitigate the flooding situation on that stretch.
The debris, he said, blocked the flow of water through the drains, and consequently resulted in flooding the area.
The Minister of Roads and Highways admitted that there was a serious storm drainage issue in the area.
The Kasoa Old Barrier area is notoriously prone to heavy vehicular traffic, a situation that gets exacerbated when it rains.
Run-off and soil washed from the hills onto the road took over one side of the dual carriage road, compelling commuters on opposite directions to use just the other side of the road.
event_breakdown:
* Flooding on the Kasoa to Winneba section of the N1
* Heavy vehicular traffic on the Kasoa Old Barrier road
* Storm drainage issues in the Kasoa Old Barrier road area

title: Houston Mayor Whitmire confirms at least four dead in powerful storm
message:
Brett Coomer/Staff photographerAt least four people died as a result of Thursday evening's powerful storm in Houston, according to Mayor John Whitmire's office.
A powerful thunderstorm tore over Houston starting around 6:30 p.m. bringing high winds and rain across wide swaths of the city.
It could take 48 hours for power to be restored throughout the city, Whitmire said.
Whitmire strongly urged people not to travel west through downtown Houston because of dangers of glass that had fallen from multiple skyscrapers.

title: Jefferson Parish opens shelter ahead of severe weather
message:
JEFFERSON PARISH, La.
(WGNO) — Jefferson Parish leaders have announced the parish’s preparations for anticipated severe weather on Thursday, May 16.
WGNO meteorologists announced a tornado watch is in effect for the Greater New Orleans area until 3 a.m. Friday.
They said the shelter will remain open until the National Weather Service “gives the all-clear that the storm has passed.”Residents planning to stay at the shelter should bring their own food and water.
New Orleans Inspector General makes recommendations for New Orleans East Hospital credit card proceduresParish officials are also advising residents to secure loose objects outside and stay inside, away from windows during severe weather conditions.

title: At least four killed and more than one million without power as wild storm topples power lines , uproots trees and blows out high - rise windows in Houston
message:
At least four people have been killed after hurricane-force winds, life-threatening flooding and torrential rains destroyed the city of Houston, Texas, yesterday.
While the National Weather Service office issued a tornado warning for the city yesterday, it was winds reaching over 70 mph that toppled trees, blew out windows and left over a million people without power.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire said in a news conference that two people were killed by downed trees and a third died after a crane toppled over.
The Houston Fire Department has advised locals to leave their homes immediately and call 911 if they smell gas in their house.
The mayor has said it would take 24 to 48 hours for power to be restored in some areas.
event_breakdown:
List of reports:
- Multiple deaths as a result of hurricane-force winds in Texas.
- Widespread destruction caused by the storm in Houston, Texas.
- Tornado warnings issued for the city.
- Falling trees depict how life-threatening it is to be outside during the hurricane.
- At least 1 million people lose power and the water is higher than over 70 feet.
- The crane fell and killed the third victim.
- The fire department warned people to leave.
- The mayor makes it very big, more powerful and dangerous from nothing to very little.

title: Houston metro rocked by severe storms that left 4 dead and over 1 million without power
message:
HOUSTON - A line of severe thunderstorms swept through southeastern Texas and Louisiana on Thursday, blasting the Houston area with ferocious winds that left at least four dead and more than 1 million power customers without electricity.
The line of storms eventually raced east into Louisiana, pummeling New Orleans with gusts of 84 mph and leaving over 200,000 in Louisiana without power.
Local residents described the impacts of the storm as being hurricane-like despite the severe weather lasting less than an hour.
Ground stops were also issued at Bush Intercontinental Airport and Houston William P. Hobby Airport due to the severe weather.
Original article source: Houston metro rocked by severe storms that left 4 dead and over 1 million without power

title: At least 4 dead in Houston as destructive storms lash Texas and Louisiana with strong winds and flood threats
message:
Major flooding has prompted water rescues in at least one Texas city.
More than 200,000 are also without power in Louisiana as storms batter the state.
Possible tornadoes posed a risk in Texas and Louisiana, and carried the threat of destructive winds and golf ball-sized hail.
Texas and Louisiana have been in the bull’s-eye of seemingly unrelenting rounds of torrential, flooding downpours since the start of April.
A tornado warning had been issued earlier Thursday evening in Harris County, including downtown Houston, according to the National Weather Service.
event_breakdown: - A number of other cities such as New Waverly, Splendora, Richards and Plantersville are also dealing with significant flooding, the NWS said. - Some of the heaviest flooding impacts are occurring in northeast Harris County, including the downtown area of Houston, Texas. - The NWS issued a flash flood emergency for Splendora, Texas, saying at the time the city’s National Weather Service radar was showing 18 inches of rain fell in about an hour. - This was true for Jackson County as well. Debris lined the streets, which looked like rivers themselves, as residents waded and paddled through them in boats. - In Texas, widespread rainfall totals of 8 to 18 inches occurred while states of emergency have been declared in Harris, Liberty, Montgomery and Waller counties.

title: Hope for Fort Nelson as rain drenches flames
message:
A rainy Thursday in and around Fort Nelson was exactly what fire crews were looking for.
Wildfire Service, fire behaviour specialist for the Parker Lake and Patry Creek blazes Evan Peck said recent rain was much needed and made for excellent conditions for fire suppression crews.
While more rain is forecast in the coming days, Peck says there's not been nearly enough precipitation yet to overcome long-term drought conditions in northeast British Columbia.
Crews continue to battle the Parker Lake and Patry Creek blazes, both of which are threatening Fort Nelson and are classified as out of control.
To date, the Parker Lake wildfire burning two kilometres west of town has forced thousands to evacuate and is holding steady at 123 square kilometres in size.
event_breakdown: Parker Lake Fire, Patry Creek Fire

title: WFP seeks 523 mln USD to scale up humanitarian response in East Africa
message:
You are here:视频播放位置 下载安装Flash播放器NAIROBI, May 17 (Xinhua) -- The UN World Food Program (WFP) said Friday it requires 523 million U.S. dollars for its humanitarian response in East Africa.
According to the UN agency, about 774,278 people have been affected by heavy rains and flash floods in the region since March.
WFP said it is responding across the region, meeting humanitarian needs stemming from the heavy rains and flooding by providing food and nutrition assistance to over 207,794 flood-affected people.
"The scale of the crisis surpasses the current response capacity, underscoring the urgent need for additional support for WFP to effectively reach the flood-affected people with life-saving food and nutrition assistance," WFP said.
The UN has projected that the heavy rains and floods could potentially affect up to 770,000 people across 22 districts in Somalia.

title: Regional Bureau for Eastern Africa floods update # 1 ( 15 May 2024 ) - Kenya
message:
Key Highlights• Approximately 774,278 people have been affected by heavy rains and flash floods in the region since the MarchMay rains started.
• More than 350,155 people have been displaced across Burundi, Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia and Uganda.
• In Somalia, WFP provided cash assistance as part of anticipatory actions reaching 149,694 people before the floods hit, enabling recipients to protect their lives and assets from the impacts of the floods.
• In Kenya, heavy rains and flash floods have left 281,835 people (56,367 households) displaced and nearly 380,573 people affected, according to the Office for coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA).
• In Burundi, 179,200 people have been affected by the floods and require humanitarian assistance, with some 31,200 people displaced.

title: What was it like when four hurricanes tormented Florida ? Let take a look
message:
Way back in 2004, four hurricanes made landfall in Florida — Charley, Frances, Ivan and Jeanne — the most recorded for the state in a single year.
Hurricane Jeanne smashed the Treasure Coast, leaving the area crippled again only three weeks after Hurricane Frances.
The park still had partial flooding from Hurricane Frances when it got hit by Jeanne.
Hurricane Frances batters sailboat and a houseboat on a pier in Stuart (about noon on Sept. 5, 2004.)
Forecasters said Charley’s outlying squalls could touch South Florida today, with 35 mph winds and two to five inches of rain, though some areas could receive more.

title: Power outages from Houston deadly hurricane - force winds could last weeks as temperatures soar
message:
(CNN) — Power outages could last for weeks in the Houston area amid soaring temperatures after a destructive complex of storms with winds up to 100 mph tore through the area Thursday, killing at least four people and crumpling critical power infrastructure.
It’s a troubling timeframe for power restoration, especially as high temperatures reach the 90s through the weekend and beyond.
Houston area bears brunt of destructive stormsHouston’s mayor advised residents to stay off the roads and stay at home because of widespread damage to the area.
The storm was so powerful it blew out the windows of buildings in downtown Houston, littering the area with glass as traffic lights went dark.
CenterPoint Energy says its skyscraper in downtown Houston sustained damage from the storm, according to a spokesperson.

- High temperatures reaching the 90s through the weekend and beyond
- Widespread damage to the area

- Traffic lights going dark in downtown Houston
- Skyscraper in downtown Houston sustaining damage

message:
Getty Images - STOCK(HOUSTON) -- At least five people were killed when a powerful storm tore through Houston on Thursday night, officials said.
Straight-line winds peaked at around 100 mph in downtown Houston, and residents told ABC News the winds sounded like a freight train.
The winds were so powerful, Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said they were comparable to Hurricane Alicia in 1983.
Houston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay home Friday following the "exceptionally" strong storm, noting 2,500 traffic lights are not functioning.
The storm in Houston is now over, allowing residents to begin to cleaning up on Friday.

title: Fort Nelson wildfires : Rainy weather brings some relief
message:
A rainy day in and around Fort Nelson, B.C., was what fire crews were hoping for as they continue to battle a wildfire burning 2.5 kilometres outside the town.
Evan Peck with the BC Wildfire Service said a low-pressure system brought much-needed rain over the last two days, along with cooler temperatures and lower humidity, making for "excellent" conditions for fire suppression efforts.
The fire is now mapped at 123 square kilometres in size, slightly lower than an earlier estimate of 127 square kilometres on Thursday.
"Recent weather has reduced the fire behaviour to smouldering ground fire, preventing fire growth," he said of the blaze that spans 718 square kilometres.
The BC Wildfire Service says the Patry Creek fire isn't an immediate threat to the town, but conditions can change rapidly if there are strong northerly winds.

title: Why climate migration in Brazil has become a global crisis
message:
“Most climate-driven migration and displacement will be internal,” Alex Randall, head of programs at Climate Outreach and specialist in climate-driven migration, told ABC News, adding, “As climate-driven disasters become more regular and more extreme, inevitably more people will be displaced by those events.”What is climate migration?
Climate migration, or climate-related mobility, refers to the sudden or gradual displacement of individuals due to changes in the environment affecting their living conditions, according to the United Nations International Organization for Migration.
According to the Migration Data Portal, at least 7.7 million people in 82 countries and territories are living in internal displacement as a result of climate disasters.
“This is one of many warning signs,” Lawrence Huang, policy analyst for the Migration Policy Institute, told ABC News of the ongoing flooding in Brazil.
“There’s such a wide range of things we call climate migration, some of it is voluntary, some of it is forced.
event_breakdown:
1. flooding in Brazil
2. DR Congo - since May 2021, approx. 55,000 people affected; more than 33,000 houses fully destroyed
3. East Africa - especially in Ethiopia, one million internally displaced
4. Honduras - 700,000 people living with loss and damage from hurricanes over the past 56 years
5. The Mediterranean - 600,000 people migrated from the north to the south of the Mediterranean; most of them fled war-torn areas.

title: Deadly Storm With Hurricane - Force Gusts Wreaks Havoc On Houston , Trashes Skyscrapers
message:
Thunderstorms with hurricane-force winds have torn through the city of Houston, knocking down trees and powerlines as well as damaging buildings, according to The Associated Press (AP).
Houston Mayor John Whitmire said there were at least four deaths due to Thursday’s storm, according to a press conference.
Wind speeds potentially reached 100 mph “with some twisters mixed into this strong wind,” Whitmire said in the press conference.
The Gulf Coast can still expect scattered and severe thunderstorms, according to The AP.
The storm may possibly reach areas of central Alabama and eastern Louisiana, according to the National Weather Service.

message:
Exceptional windstorms that could leave some Houston residents without power for weeks were a once-in-a-generation event and the damage left in their wake is comparable to that caused by a hurricane, meteorologists said Friday.
At least four people died after the storms barreled through Houston on Thursday.
Workers repair a damaged street light downtown on Friday, May 17, 2024, in Houston, after a strong thunderstorm moved through Thursday evening.
Straight-line winds gusting over 80 mph in a single direction have been blamed for the damage, Maldonado said.
___This story has been corrected to show the Houston suburb hit by a tornado is Cypress, not Cyprus.
event_breakdown: The events mentioned in the text are the Houston windstorm (a windstorm that left some residents without power for weeks) and the Cypress, Texas tornado.

title: Crews fighting wildfires near Fort Nelson hope skies open up after rainy Thursday – Brandon Sun
message:
FORT NELSON, B.C.
Northern Rockies Regional Municipality Mayor Rob Fraser said it was “insensitive” and “unconscionable” that images of properties destroyed by the Parker Lake wildfire outside Fort Nelson had been shared before owners were told of the damage by authorities.
Fraser’s comments come after videos were posted on social media showing what appeared to be multiple homes destroyed outside Fort Nelson.
An extreme fire warning sign is shown along Highway 97 toward Fort Nelson outside the Charlie Lake Fire Hall near Fort St. John, B.C., on Monday, May 13, 2024.
It said more than 100 wildfire service firefighters were responding to the Fort Nelson fires, as well as about 60 structure protection firefighters and 19 helicopters.
event_breakdown:
- Destructive wildfires occurred outside of Fort Nelson, BC, in 2024.
- The Parker Lake wildfire destroyed multiple properties, as shown on social media.
- 100+ wildfire service firefighters, 60 structure protection firefighters, 19 helicopters, responded to wildfires outside Fort Nelson.
